Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
Postdoctoral Fellow: Gregory Stull
Proposal Number: 1612032

This award funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2017, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to take transformative approaches to grand challenges in biology that employ biological collections in highly innovative ways. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Gregory W. Stull is "Integrating diverse collections data for deep-time distribution modeling in a tropical flowering plant family (Icacinaceae) with an extensive fossil record." The host institution for this fellowship is University of Michigan, and the sponsoring scientists are Stephen A. Smith and Christopher W. Dick.

The goal of this research is to explore using geographic data from modern species to generate species distribution models of extinct species, thereby allowing for the reconstruction of species distribution patterns across broad time scales. The research uses the tropical plant family Icacinaceae, which has an extensive fossil record, as a model group of organisms, and investigates the climatic suitability of major land bridges/rafts for the migration of tropical plants throughout the Cenozoic Era (65 million years ago to the present). The research is important because understanding how species have responded to previous climate change can help predict the impact of future climate change on the distribution of current biological diversity. Because the fossil record is incomplete, additional tools are necessary to reconstruct historical distributions at different points in the past (e.g., during the early Eocene, when the earth?s climate was considerably warmer than the present). The Fellow is using species distribution modeling (SDM), which has emerged as a powerful computational tool for modeling the ecological requirements of species, incorporating the wealth of locality/geographic data available for modern species in natural history collections. SDM has been used extensively to predict possible future distributions as shaped by climate change. However, the application of SDM for reconstructing distributions in deep time has been underexplored, despite its potential for understanding how climate change has shaped the diversity and distribution of organisms through time. The Fellow's research constitutes one of the first applications of SDM across such a broad time scale, using the fossil record to validate the results. This research therefore serves as an important proof of concept for this approach, and the novel methodological tools generated will advance future research related to biogeography and climate change.

In terms of training, the Fellow is acquiring skills in bioinformatics and computational biology, particularly related to methods of species distribution modeling and biogeographic modeling. These skills (e.g., fluency in scripting/programming languages such as Python) are becoming increasingly important in biological research, and this research will therefore prepare the Fellow well for a career focused on research using biological collections. The products of this work are being distributed to the research community through a variety of outlets including peer-reviewed publications, international conferences, a workshop, and web tutorials. The Fellow is also mentoring and training two undergraduates per year, seeking out individuals from minority groups underrepresented in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored novel methods of integrating diverse data types (morphology, DNA sequences, fossils, and climatic information) for reconstructions of evolutionary history, focusing in particular on species relationships, patterns of morphological evolution, and changes in geographic distribution in response to climatic changes over the past 65 million years. The tropical flowering plant family Icacinaceae was used as a model group because of its rich fossil record, and the Icacinaceae were additionally placed in a broader evolutionary context though investigations of Asteridae (ca. 40,000 species), the major angiosperm group to which Icacinaceae belongs. 

 In terms of Intellectual Merit, this project provided novel insight into the phylogenetic relationships, fossil record, and biogeographic history of Icacinaceae, with important implications for the evolutionary history of tropical plants in general as well as the significance of particular pathways for tropical plant migration during the Paleogene (ca. 66 to 23 million years ago). Several new fossil species of Icacinaceae were described as a result of this project and, along with numerous other previously documented fossils of the family, placed in a broader evolutionary context. Phylogenomic and morphological reconstructions of Asteridae also provided novel insights on relationships among major lineages and the morphological features that characterize major groups within Asteridae. In terms of Broader Impacts, this project provided significant training and professional development opportunities for the PI (Gregory Stull), who gained important skills in programming, bioinformatics, and phylogenetic methods. The PI also established new professional contacts and collaborators at University of Michigan, and served as a mentor for two undergraduate research projects. 

 During the course of the NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship, the PI (Gregory Stull) served as the lead author or co-author on five research articles (published in or submitted to the journals: American Journal of Botany, International Journal of Plant Sciences, Proceedings of the Royal Society B, and Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology) and presented research results at national and international botanical conferences (Botany 2018 in Rochester, MN, and the International Botanical Congress 2017 in Shenzhen, China). Additional results stemming from this postdoc are being finalized and prepared for additional research publications. 


Last Modified: 05/10/2019
Modified by: Gregory W Stull
